awd_titl_txt: Bringing Land, Ocean, Atmosphere and Ionosphere Data to the Community for Hazards Alerts
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Convergence Accelerator supports use-inspired, team-based, multidisciplinary efforts that address challenges of national importance and will produce deliverables of value to society in the near future. The objective of this workshop on Bringing Land, Ocean, Atmosphere and Ionosphere Data to the Community for Hazards Alerts is to help identify topic areas for new tracks in the NSF Convergence Accelerator.

This workshop will bring together Earth System scientists engaged in research on land, ocean, atmosphere, cryosphere and ionosphere phenomena to discuss land-based natural hazards and the impact of such hazards on corresponding parts of the Earth system, viz., ocean, atmosphere, cryosphere, and ionosphere, as well as on human populations in the vicinity of those hazards.  Much of the research on natural hazards has tended to focus on one Earth system – for example, tropical storms are studied primarily by ocean scientists, and not as much by, say, earth or atmospheric scientists. However, increasing availability of ground-based, borehole and satellite-based observations at higher spatial and temporal resolution over the globe, and optical and microwave satellites capable of providing meteorological and atmospheric parameters at different pressure levels, are enabling more detailed analyses that show stronger coupling among various Earth systems due to natural hazards. 

This Convergence Accelerator workshop will provide a platform for ideation and brainstorming on using all available data sources to develop an “alert system” for natural hazards, and to communicate such information to people via various social and digital media in order to reduce loss of life and property and protect human health. The workshop will bring together experts in ground, surface, meteorological and atmospheric data, together with social science researchers, city planners and other local government stakeholders, representatives from non-governmental organizations and those assisting in disaster management to discuss the needs as well as effective approaches for reaching the affected communities during a natural hazard.  

The workshop will help advance understanding of coupled land-ocean-cryosphere-meteorological-ionosphere systems in the context of natural hazards of all types, and their impact on local/regional infrastructure, resources and people. The key objective of the workshop is to advance the use of all available data from different platforms and leverage the myriad social and digital media platforms to alert the community and get them prepared for impending hazards.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The workshop was focused to bring Earth System Scientists from different continents to study the changes on the land, ocean, atmosphere, biosphere cryosphere, and meteorological parameters using ground and satellite data to find out the disaster-vulnerable zones. All kinds of natural hazards are associated with different Earth's spheres, some of these natural hazards are driven by meteorological parameters which are now easily monitored using satellites at different pressure levels. In order to understand natural hazards processes, understanding the interaction of land, ocean, biosphere, cryosphere, and atmosphere are important. Understanding coupling among these spheres helps us to develop early warning of these natural hazards. The workshop was attended by more than six hundred people from different continents where the geological, geophysical, meteorological,  atmospheric, and hydrological parameters have contrasting differences. The workshop runs for five days, morning and evening to take care of different time zones of people living on different continents.  There were a number of cases presented by scientists from different continents. The gap in ground data was discussed. The past and future satellite missions and their need to monitor all kinds of natural hazards were brought out. Natural hazards like tsunamis, earthquakes, and volcanoes have shown an impact on the ionosphere changes which are being monitored using GPS and GNSS systems. The recent data have shown promising results to use ionospheric parameters for the early warning of a few natural hazards. Communication with the population, at the time of natural hazards, was stressed and its importance was identified. A session was organized in this workshop, on how to use social media Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn, etc. to communicate with people living in vulnerable areas or to provide alert systems at the time of different natural hazards. This is the first time; Earth Scientists realized the importance of strong coupling among different continents associated with many natural hazards.  The importance of the ground and satellite observing systems in saving the lives of people affected by different natural hazards in the past was discussed and it was an overwhelming response on how the current observing systems have minimized loss of life using these data to evacuate vulnerable areas due to an impending natural hazard.
